q: Who invaded India in AD 712 and conquered Sindh?
desc: Mohammad bin Qasim led the first successful Arab invasion of India in AD 712 and conquered Sindh.

q: How many expeditions did Mahmud of Ghazni lead into India?
desc: Mahmud of Ghazni led around 17 expeditions into India, mainly for plundering wealth.

q: Which famous Hindu temple did Mahmud of Ghazni raid in 1025?
desc: In 1025, Mahmud of Ghazni raided the Somnath temple located on the Kathiawar coast.

q: Where was the Somnath temple situated?
desc: The Somnath temple is located in Kathiawar, which is in present-day Gujarat.

q: Who defeated Mohammad Ghori in the First Battle of Tarain?
desc: In 1191, Prithviraj Chauhan defeated Mohammad Ghori in the First Battle of Tarain.

q: When did the First Battle of Tarain take place?
desc: The First Battle of Tarain took place in 1191 between Mohammad Ghori and Prithviraj Chauhan.

q: Who won the Second Battle of Tarain in 1192?
desc: Mohammad Ghori defeated Prithviraj Chauhan in the Second Battle of Tarain in 1192.

q: Which battle laid the foundation of Muslim rule in India?
desc: The Second Battle of Tarain in 1192 is considered the beginning of Muslim rule in India.

q: Who is considered the founder of Muslim rule in India?
desc: Mohammad Ghori is regarded as the founder of Muslim rule in India after his victory at Tarain.

q: When was the Ilbari Dynasty founded?
desc: The Ilbari Dynasty, also known as the Slave Dynasty, was founded in AD 1206.

q: Who founded the Slave Dynasty?
desc: Qutub-ud-din Aibak founded the Slave Dynasty in 1206 after the death of Mohammad Ghori.

q: What was the initial capital of Qutub-ud-din Aibak?
desc: Qutub-ud-din Aibak initially ruled from Lahore before shifting the capital to Delhi.

q: What was Qutub-ud-din Aibak popularly called due to his generosity?
desc: Qutub-ud-din Aibak was nicknamed 'Lakh Baksh' for his generosity and donations.

q: Who laid the foundation of Qutub Minar?
desc: Qutub-ud-din Aibak initiated the construction of the Qutub Minar in Delhi.

q: The Qutub Minar was named after which famous Sufi saint?
desc: Qutub Minar was named after Khwaja Qutubuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki, a revered Sufi saint.

q: Which mosque was the first to be built in India?
desc: Quwwat-ul-Islam mosque in Delhi is the first mosque built in India by Qutub-ud-din Aibak.

q: Where is Adhai Din ka Jhopra located?
desc: Adhai Din ka Jhopra, a mosque built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak, is located in Ajmer.

q: How did Qutub-ud-din Aibak die?
desc: Qutub-ud-din Aibak died after a fall from his horse while playing Chaugan (polo) in Lahore.

q: What game was Qutub-ud-din Aibak playing when he died?
desc: Chaugan, a form of polo, was being played by Qutub-ud-din Aibak at the time of his death.

q: Which dynasty was also known as the Mamluk Dynasty?
desc: The Slave Dynasty is also referred to as the Mamluk Dynasty in Indian history.

q: Who was the spiritual inspiration behind the name Qutub Minar?
desc: Qutub Minar was named to honor the Sufi saint Qutubuddin Bakhtiyar Kaki.

q: What does 'Adhai Din ka Jhopra' literally mean?
pool: Cottage of Two and a Half Days
answer: Cottage of Two and a Half Days
desc: 'Adhai Din ka Jhopra' translates to 'Cottage of Two and a Half Days'.

q: Where did Mohammad Ghori come from?
desc: Mohammad Ghori hailed from Ghor, in present-day Afghanistan.

q: Which Rajput king was defeated in the Second Battle of Tarain?
desc: Prithviraj Chauhan was defeated by Mohammad Ghori in 1192 at the Second Battle of Tarain.

q: Who succeeded Mohammad Ghori in India?
desc: Qutub-ud-din Aibak, Ghori's general, took over after his master's death and became Sultan.

q: What religion did Mahmud of Ghazni and Mohammad Ghori follow?
desc: Both Mahmud of Ghazni and Mohammad Ghori were Muslim invaders from Central Asia.

q: Which monument is associated with both religious and architectural significance during Aibak's rule?
desc: Qutub Minar is a famous minaret begun by Qutub-ud-din Aibak and completed by Iltutmish.

q: Which city became the political center under Qutub-ud-din Aibak?
desc: Though Aibak started in Lahore, he eventually made Delhi his political center.

q: Which Sultan built the Quwwat-ul-Islam mosque?
desc: Qutub-ud-din Aibak built the Quwwat-ul-Islam mosque in Delhi.

q: Who formed the Turkan-e-Chahalgani or Chalisa?
desc: Iltutmish formed the Chalisa, a group of 40 powerful Turkish nobles, to strengthen his administration.

q: What was the Chalisa?
desc: The Chalisa was a council of 40 powerful Turkish nobles formed by Iltutmish.

q: How did Iltutmish manage salaries for officials?
desc: Iltutmish divided his empire into Iqtas, land assigned to officials in lieu of salary.

q: Which coin types were introduced by Iltutmish?
desc: Iltutmish introduced two coin types: the silver tanka and copper jital.

q: When did Iltutmish rule Delhi?
desc: Iltutmish ruled from AD 1210 to 1236 and laid strong administrative foundations.

q: Who was the first and only Muslim woman ruler of medieval India?
desc: Razia Sultan was the first and only Muslim woman ruler of medieval India, ruling from 1236 to 1240.

q: Which governor did Razia Sultan marry?
desc: Razia Sultan married Altunia, the governor of Bhatinda.

q: Who killed Razia Sultan?
desc: Razia Sultan was killed by Bahram Shah, her brother and son of Iltutmish.

q: Which practice was introduced by Balban to emphasize royal authority?
desc: Balban introduced Sijdah and Paibos to strengthen the divine image of the king.

q: What does 'Niyabat-e-Khudai' mean?
desc: Balban proclaimed the king as 'Niyabat-e-Khudai', meaning deputy of God.

q: What title did Balban use to describe himself as God's representative?
desc: Balban referred to himself as 'Zil-e-Illahi', meaning the shadow of God.

q: What were Diwan-e-Ariz and Diwan-e-Wazarat?
desc: Balban separated the Military Department (Diwan-e-Ariz) and Finance Department (Diwan-e-Wazarat).

q: Who ruled Delhi from AD 1266 to 1286?
desc: Balban ruled Delhi from AD 1266 to 1286 and implemented strict court discipline.

q: Which dynasty ruled from AD 1290 to 1320?
desc: The Khalji Dynasty ruled from AD 1290 to 1320 and expanded the empire significantly.

q: Who was the first ruler of the Khalji Dynasty?
desc: Jalaluddin Firuz Khalji was the founder of the Khalji Dynasty in 1290.

q: What belief did Jalaluddin Firuz Khalji hold about India?
pool: It cannot be a fully Islamic state
It should be ruled by nobles
It should not have a capital
It must be divided into provinces
answer: It cannot be a fully Islamic state
desc: Jalaluddin believed India could not be a fully Islamic state due to its diverse population.

q: Who succeeded Jalaluddin Firuz Khalji?
desc: Alauddin Khalji succeeded Jalaluddin Firuz Khalji and expanded the empire significantly.

q: Which southern general led Alauddin Khalji's southern campaigns?
desc: Malik Kafur led Alauddin Khalji’s southern conquests to expand the Delhi Sultanate.

q: Which regions were conquered by Alauddin Khalji?
desc: Alauddin Khalji expanded his empire to Gujarat, Chittor, Ranthambhor, and Malwa.

q: Which economic policy was implemented by Alauddin Khalji in Doab?
desc: Alauddin Khalji did not allow iqtas in the fertile Doab region to retain direct revenue control.

q: What did Alauddin Khalji abolish in Khalisa land?
desc: Alauddin abolished Zamindari in Khalisa land to assert state control over revenue.

q: Which Sultan is credited for ending the iqta system in some areas?
desc: Alauddin Khalji ended the iqta system in the Doab region to increase direct state revenue.

q: Who introduced Sijdah and Paibos in the royal court?
desc: Balban introduced the court practices of Sijdah and Paibos to assert royal authority.

q: Which woman ruler in medieval India married the governor of Bhatinda?
desc: Razia Sultan married Altunia, governor of Bhatinda, during her reign.

q: Who reviewed that India cannot be a totally Islamic state?
desc: Jalaluddin Firuz Khalji acknowledged India's religious diversity and declared it couldn't be wholly Islamic.

q: Who was responsible for the Mongol threat during his reign?
desc: During Iltutmish’s reign, India faced threats from Mongol invasions.

q: What is a 'Khalisa' land?
pool: Royal land directly controlled by the state
answer: Royal land directly controlled by the state
desc: Khalisa land referred to land under direct state administration without intermediaries like zamindars.

q: Who ruled Delhi immediately after Iltutmish?
desc: Razia Sultan, daughter of Iltutmish, succeeded him as ruler in AD 1236.

q: Who was killed by his own daughter, Razia Sultan?
desc: Razia Sultan was herself killed by Bahram Shah; she did not kill anyone in her family.

q: Which Sultan adopted the policy of Blood and Iron to tackle the Mongols?
desc: Alauddin Khalji adopted the policy of Blood and Iron to deal with Mongol invasions.

q: Which city was built by Alauddin Khalji as his capital?
desc: Alauddin Khalji built the city of Siri and made it his capital.

q: What significant structure did Alauddin Khalji add an entrance to?
desc: Alauddin Khalji added an entrance door to the Qutub Minar.

q: Which title did Alauddin Khalji adopt?
desc: Alauddin Khalji called himself Sikandar-i-Sani, meaning Second Alexander.

q: What was the Chehra and Dagh system introduced by Alauddin Khalji related to?
desc: The Chehra (face registry) and Dagh (branding of horses) system were military reforms.

q: Who was the first Turkish Sultan to separate religion from politics?
desc: Alauddin Khalji separated religion from politics, emphasizing a secular approach to governance.

q: Which famous poet was present in Alauddin Khalji's court?
desc: Amir Khusrau, a renowned poet and musician, was in Alauddin Khalji's court.

q: Who founded the Tughlaq Dynasty?
desc: Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq founded the Tughlaq Dynasty and built Tughlaqabad.

q: Which city did Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq make his capital?
desc: Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq established Tughlaqabad as his capital city.

q: Who is known as the 'wise fool' king?
desc: Muhammad bin Tughlaq was called the 'wise fool' due to his ambitious yet impractical experiments.

q: Which was not one of Muhammad bin Tughlaq’s five experiments?
desc: Muhammad bin Tughlaq never introduced the rupee; his notable experiments included token currency and capital transfer.

q: Where did Muhammad bin Tughlaq transfer his capital to?
desc: Muhammad bin Tughlaq transferred his capital from Delhi to Daulatabad to strengthen control over the Deccan.

q: Which department was set up by Muhammad bin Tughlaq for agriculture?
desc: Muhammad bin Tughlaq established Diwan-i-Kohi to promote agriculture and improve farming.

q: What type of loans were given to farmers under Muhammad bin Tughlaq?
desc: Sondhar loans were extended to farmers to encourage agricultural productivity.

q: Who was the Moroccan traveler that visited the court of Muhammad bin Tughlaq?
desc: Ibn Battuta, the Moroccan traveler, visited the court of Muhammad bin Tughlaq and recorded his experiences.

q: Which ruler founded the towns of Hissar, Firozpur, Fatehabad, and Jaunpur?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq founded several towns including Firozabad and Hissar.

q: What was Firozabad during Firoz Shah Tughlaq’s reign?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq made Firozabad his capital city.

q: Which ruler brought Ashokan pillars from Topara and Meerut?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq transported two Ashokan pillars to Delhi from Topara and Meerut.

q: What book was written by Firoz Shah Tughlaq?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq wrote *Fatuhat-e-Firozshahi*, detailing his reign and reforms.

q: What major architectural repair was undertaken by Firoz Shah Tughlaq?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq repaired Qutub Minar after it was damaged by lightning.

q: What system did Firoz Shah Tughlaq make hereditary?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq made the Iqtadari system, a system of land grants, hereditary.

q: What was 'Kharaj' under Firoz Shah Tughlaq?
desc: Kharaj was a land tax equal to one-tenth of the produce.

q: What was 'Khams' under the Tughlaq administration?
desc: Khams was a tax levied on one-tenth of the spoils of war.

q: What tax was imposed on Brahmans by Firoz Shah Tughlaq for the first time?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq imposed Jizya tax on Brahmans for the first time in Sultanate history.

q: Which Tughlaq ruler was fond of collecting slaves?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq maintained a large number of slaves and was known for his fondness for them.

q: Which canal-building ruler is remembered for water conservation efforts?
desc: Firoz Shah Tughlaq is credited with initiating canal construction for irrigation.

q: Which dynasty witnessed the foundation of Bahmani and Vijayanagara empires?
desc: The Tughlaq dynasty period saw the emergence of the Bahmani and Vijayanagara kingdoms in the south.

q: Which Tughlaq ruler failed in the Qarachil expedition?
desc: Muhammad bin Tughlaq's Qarachil expedition to the Himalayas ended in failure.

q: Which Sultan’s reforms earned him the nickname ‘mad genius’ or ‘wise fool’?
desc: His ambitious reforms, although well-intentioned, often failed, earning him the title 'wise fool.'

q: Which of the following coins was NOT introduced by the Tughlaq ruler?
desc: Gaz-i-Sikandari was a unit of measurement introduced by Sikander Lodhi, not a coin.

q: Who ordered the general massacre in Delhi in 1398?
desc: Timur, the Mongol leader, ordered the massacre during his invasion of Delhi in 1398.

q: Under which ruler did the massacre in Delhi occur in 1398?
desc: The massacre happened during the reign of Nasiruddin Mahmud, the last Tughlaq ruler.

q: Who founded the Sayyid dynasty?
desc: Khizr Khan founded the Sayyid dynasty after Timur's invasion.

q: Who among the following was NOT a Sayyid ruler?
desc: Bahlol Lodhi was the founder of the Lodhi dynasty, not a Sayyid ruler.

q: The Lodhis were the first __________ to rule India.
desc: The Lodhi dynasty was the first Afghan dynasty to rule parts of India.

q: Who founded the Lodhi dynasty?
desc: Bahlol Lodhi founded the Lodhi dynasty in 1451.

q: Which Lodhi ruler introduced the Gaz-i-Sikandari?
desc: Sikander Lodhi introduced the Gaz-i-Sikandari as a unit to measure agricultural land.

q: Who founded the city of Agra in 1504?
desc: Sikander Lodhi founded the city of Agra in 1504.

q: Which Persian verse was composed by Sikander Lodhi?
desc: Sikander Lodhi wrote the Persian verse 'Gulrukhi'.

q: Who defeated Ibrahim Lodhi in the Battle of Khatoli?
desc: Rana Sanga of Mewar defeated Ibrahim Lodhi at the Battle of Khatoli.

q: In which year was Ibrahim Lodhi defeated by Babur?
desc: Babur defeated Ibrahim Lodhi in the First Battle of Panipat in 1526, starting Mughal rule.

q: Who was the last Lodhi ruler?
desc: Ibrahim Lodhi was the last Lodhi ruler before the Mughal conquest.

q: When did Gujarat break away from the Delhi Sultanate?
desc: Gujarat broke away from Delhi in 1397 under Zafar Khan.

q: Who assumed the title of Sultan Muzaffar Shah in Gujarat?
desc: Zafar Khan took the title of Sultan Muzaffar Shah after establishing rule in Gujarat.

q: Which city was built by Ahmed Shah I?
desc: Ahmed Shah I founded Ahmedabad in Gujarat.

q: Which Gujarat ruler allowed the Portuguese to set up a factory at Diu?
desc: Mahmud Beghra ruled Gujarat when the Portuguese established a factory at Diu.

q: Who asserted independence in Kashmir in 1339?
desc: Shamsuddin Shah established his rule in Kashmir in 1339.

q: Which Kashmiri ruler is known as the Akbar of Kashmir?
desc: Zain-ul-Abidin is called the Akbar of Kashmir for his reforms and tolerance.

q: What is Zaina Lank?
desc: Zaina Lank is an artificial island in Wular Lake built by Zain-ul-Abidin.

q: Who restored Rajput rule in Mewar after Alauddin Khilji's invasion?
desc: Rana Hamir restored Rajput rule in Mewar after Alauddin Khilji's capture of Chittor.

q: Who built the Vijay Stambh at Chittor?
desc: Rana Kumbha built Vijay Stambh to commemorate his victory over Mahmud Khalji.

q: Whom did Rana Kumbha defeat to build the Vijay Stambh?
desc: Rana Kumbha defeated Mahmud Khalji of Malwa and built the Vijay Stambh at Chittor.

q: Which lake houses the Zaina Lank?
desc: Zaina Lank is located in Wular Lake in Kashmir.

q: In what year did Timur invade Delhi?
desc: Timur invaded Delhi and caused a massacre in the year 1398.

q: Who ruled Delhi at the time of Timur's invasion?
desc: Timur invaded during the reign of Nasiruddin Mahmud, the last Tughlaq ruler.

q: Who was the founder of the Gujarat Sultanate?
desc: Zafar Khan broke away from Delhi and founded the Gujarat Sultanate.

q: Who was the greatest ruler of Kashmir?
desc: Zain-ul-Abidin is regarded as the greatest ruler of Kashmir for his enlightened rule.

q: Which Lodhi ruler was in power when Babur invaded India?
desc: Ibrahim Lodhi was defeated by Babur in 1526, marking the start of Mughal rule.

q: Who were the founders of the Vijayanagara Empire?
desc: Harihara I and Bukka I founded the Vijayanagara Empire in 1336.

q: Which of the following was NOT a dynasty of the Vijayanagara Empire?
desc: Maurya was an ancient Indian dynasty, not part of Vijayanagara's ruling dynasties.

q: Who built a dam across the Tungabhadra river?
desc: Devaraya I built a dam across the Tungabhadra river for irrigation and water management.

q: Which foreign traveler visited the court of Devaraya I?
desc: Nicolo de Conti, an Italian traveler, visited the court of Devaraya I.

q: Who was the Russian merchant who visited Vijayanagara?
desc: Nikitin was a Russian merchant who visited the Vijayanagara Empire.

q: Who was known as ‘Gajabetekara’ and wrote Mahanataka Sudhanidhi?
desc: Devaraya II was called ‘Gajabetekara’ and authored Mahanataka Sudhanidhi.

q: Which Persian ambassador visited the court of Devaraya II?
desc: Persian ambassador Abdur Razzaq visited Devaraya II’s court.

q: Who is considered the greatest ruler of Vijayanagara?
desc: Krishnadeva Raya is widely regarded as the greatest ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire.

q: Which ruler was known as Abhinava Bhoja and Andhra Pitamah?
desc: Krishnadeva Raya was honored with titles like Abhinava Bhoja and Andhra Pitamah.

q: Which of the following was NOT one of Krishnadeva Raya’s titles?
desc: Gajabetekara was a title of Devaraya II, not Krishnadeva Raya.

q: What was the collective name of the eight Telugu poets in Krishnadeva Raya’s court?
desc: Eight celebrated poets in Krishnadeva Raya's court were known as the Ashta Diggaja.

q: Who among the following was part of the Ashta Diggaja?
desc: Tenalirama was one of the eight Ashta Diggajas in Krishnadeva Raya’s court.

q: Who visited the Vijayanagara court during Krishnadeva Raya’s reign?
desc: Dominigo Paes, a Portuguese traveler, visited Vijayanagara during Krishnadeva Raya’s reign.

q: Barbosa, who visited Vijayanagara, was from which country?
desc: Barbosa was a Portuguese traveler who visited Krishnadeva Raya’s court.

q: Who was the last ruler of the Tuluva dynasty?
desc: Sadasiva was the last ruler of the Tuluva dynasty of Vijayanagara.

q: The Battle of Talikota took place in which year?
desc: The Battle of Talikota in 1565 led to the decline of the Vijayanagara Empire.

q: Who defeated Vijayanagara in the Battle of Talikota?
desc: An alliance of Deccan sultanates defeated Vijayanagara in the Battle of Talikota.

q: Who founded the Bahmani Kingdom?
desc: Alauddin Hasan Bahman Shah, also known as Hasan Gangu, founded the Bahmani Kingdom.

q: What was the capital of the Bahmani Kingdom originally?
desc: Gulbarg was the original capital of the Bahmani Kingdom.

q: Who shifted the capital of the Bahmani Kingdom to Bidar?
desc: Ahmad Shah Wali transferred the Bahmani capital from Gulbarg to Bidar.

q: Which kingdom was founded by Malik Ahmad Bahri?
desc: Malik Ahmad Bahri founded the Nizamsahis of Ahmadnagar.

q: Who founded the Adilsahi kingdom of Bijapur?
desc: Yusuf Adil Shah established the Adilsahi dynasty at Bijapur.

q: Who founded the Imadsahis of Berar?
desc: Fatullah Khan Imad-ul-Mulk was the founder of the Imadsahi dynasty in Berar.

q: Who was the founder of the Qutubsahis of Golconda?
desc: Quli Qutub Shah founded the Qutubsahi dynasty at Golconda.

q: Who founded the Baridsahis of Bidar?
desc: Ali Barid established the Baridsahi dynasty in Bidar.

q: Which tomb has the world’s second-largest dome?
desc: Gol Gumbaz, built by Muhammad Adil Shah in Bijapur, has the second-largest dome in the world.

q: Who built the Gol Gumbaz in Bijapur?
desc: Muhammad Adil Shah of Bijapur built the iconic Gol Gumbaz.

q: Who built the Charminar and founded Hyderabad?
desc: Quli Qutub Shah built Charminar and founded the city of Hyderabad.
